channel.title: EXT4 is FAST
channel.description:
Long time no post, but I decided to check back here today and that reminded me that I should reinstall my Arch Linux. I did. You should too.
This is why: http://solar-blogg.blogspot.com/2009/03/ext4-is-fast.html

item.title: EXT4 is FAST
item.dc:creator: @linkmaster03 linkmaster03
item.description:
@linkmaster03 wrote:

I have no clue why I registered in the first place, but I couldn’t resist the Linux section when I came on here to poke around RS stuff.

Read full topic

item.title: EXT4 is FAST
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:21, topic:266467”][quote author=linkmaster03 link=topic=351920.msg2741461#msg2741461 date=1239387064]
I have a fresh install of Arch with ext4. It’s awesome. Fsck’s are amazingly fast.
[/quote]
6 (0.007 per day)
Eh?
You registered in 2006 and started posting now…[/quote]

So?

Perhaps that’s a good thing; gave him some time to see how not to act.
Seems like it has worked so far…

Read full topic

item.title: EXT4 is FAST
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

One example of what I am talking about is with the new ubuntu (jaunty, still in beta). Everyone talks about how fast it boots with the new ext4 filesystem, and that is true. However, what most people don’t take into account is the new kernel configuration, in which many of the modules, instead of being compiled as modules, are now built into the kernel, which is the real reason load times are decreased.

On a side note, they thought it best to compile in the ipv6 module into the kernel, reasoning that they always load it whenever the network is used anyway, which makes it impossible to disable ipv6. Luckily a new kernel is so easy to compile. Thanks ubuntu developers! :rolleyes:

Read full topic

item.title: EXT4 is FAST
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

I must admit, booting seems ridiculously fast ever since i reinstalled arch on ext4, and that’s with more daemons starting than before.

Read full topic

item.title: EXT4 is FAST
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

About 10 secs to the login command line for me. As soon as I have entered my password it is logged in and ready to use. ext4 is about 3 times faster than when I used to have ubuntu on my comp… (Yes, I know I can’t compare ubuntu to arch…)

Read full topic

item.title: EXT4 is FAST
item.dc:creator: @llib llib
item.description:
@llib wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:12, topic:266467”]MITB wants real results. I can say it goes faster, but if I say it used to take 20 seconds on average and now 10 seconds on average you back up your statement.

It’s quite psychological, if you think it goes faster, it does.[/quote]

There was no placebo here. The progress bar for the scan literally went up in chunks instead of 1 percent at a time.

Although I see where your coming from.

Read full topic

item.title: EXT4 is FAST
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Boot time is not very interesting, there are many more factors to consider than hard drive IO speed. There are good tests of flat out IO speed though, I might give some a shot later on my desktop.

Read full topic

item.title: EXT4 is FAST
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:

[quote=“solarwind, post:13, topic:266467”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=351920.msg2730313#msg2730313 date=1238674941]
MITB wants real results. I can say it goes faster, but if I say it used to take 20 seconds on average and now 10 seconds on average you back up your statement.

It’s quite psychological, if you think it goes faster, it does.
[/quote]

Time it yourself. I don’t have the time to time it… … …[/quote]

I don’t have time either.

Well, I do have time actually, but I CBA right now.

Read full topic

item.title: EXT4 is FAST
item.dc:creator: @llib llib
item.description:
@llib wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Mine is a fresh install as well. I just copied my home directory to another partition, did a fresh format and install and copied it back. I can’t really notice a difference. It would be nice if your review and claim that ext4 is fast was supported by some statistics though.

Well when it runs fsck every 35 mounts or so, I noticed a difference in speed. Even on my /home partition it went a lot faster. Which I think is half full?

Read full topic

item.title: EXT4 is FAST
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mine is a fresh install as well. I just copied my home directory to another partition, did a fresh format and install and copied it back. I can’t really notice a difference. It would be nice if your review and claim that ext4 is fast was supported by some statistics though.

Read full topic

item.title: EXT4 is FAST
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Doesn’t seem that much faster for me, neither does fsck, although I know it would be if I had a less than 91% full hard drive.

I started with a fresh install and it really sped things up - especially on my laptop (probably the delayed allocation kicking in there).

Read full topic

item.title: EXT4 is FAST
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest

item.title: EXT4 is FAST
item.dc:creator: @llib llib
item.description:
@llib wrote:

Also you’ll love it when it comes to doing a fsck, much quicker than ext3!

Ext4 is awesome, and so is Arch

Edit
Regardin your blog, Ubuntu 9.04 already has ext4 as of January, it just won’t be the default install option.

Read full topic

item.title: EXT4 is FAST
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:4, topic:266467”][quote=solar-blogg]

CPU: Intel Pentium M 750 @ 1.86 GHz

RAM: 1 GB DDR2 dual channel

[/quote]
I found that rather wierd.

Doesnt the HD speed affect this aswell? I have a on Old P3 @ 500Mhz and a really old 2gb hard disk that runs @ 4200 RPM. Will it still be as fast?[/quote]
Yes it does, I forgot to mention my HD speed. It’s probably 4200 or 5400 I forgot which. It’s not a fast drive, it’s meant to be slow and power saving so 10 second boot to a BASH shell as opposed to my previous record of 20 seconds is an impressive jump.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: March 09, 2009, 03:16:11 pm[/size][hr][quote=“Greeny, post:3, topic:266467”]I’ll have to try it once i clear some diskspace.[/quote]
You can make a 1 GB partition and install ArchLinux to it.

Read full topic

item.title: EXT4 is FAST
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:4, topic:266467”][quote=solar-blogg]

CPU: Intel Pentium M 750 @ 1.86 GHz

RAM: 1 GB DDR2 dual channel

[/quote]
I found that rather wierd.

Doesnt the HD speed affect this aswell? I have a on Old P3 @ 500Mhz and a really old 2gb hard disk that runs @ 4200 RPM. Will it still be as fast?[/quote]

Of course it does, but 7200RPM SATA is almost standard in desktops now. Also if it’s a SATA drive, there are two types: I and II (SATA/300). SATA II is faster.

Read full topic
